description:
Algoriphagus aquimarinus is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It is a gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Algoriphagus aquimarinus was first isolated from seawater collected near the coast of the East China Sea.

The cells of Algoriphagus aquimarinus are typically rod-shaped, with a size range of 0.4-0.6 μm in width and 1.2-2.5 μm in length. The bacterium is motile, with gliding motility, and is capable of growing at temperatures ranging from 10°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature of around 25°C.

Algoriphagus aquimarinus is capable of hydrolyzing a variety of complex organic compounds, such as starch, casein, and gelatin, indicating its ability to utilize a diverse range of nutrient sources. It is also known to produce carotenoid pigments, which contribute to its characteristic orange-yellow colony color.

The genome of Algoriphagus aquimarinus has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and adaptations to the marine environment. This information contributes to our understanding of the ecological roles and potential applications of this bacterial species in various biotechnological and environmental processes.
